column12: A system can be considered stable in the face of adisturbance if (1) it retains a similar structure ("resistance")or (2) it returns to a similar pre-disturbancestructure after an initial deviation ("resilience"; Connelland Sousa 1983).

Continued coral recruitment and growth of fast growing species appear important.

The seagrass are affected by both temperatures above a certain threshold value and increased duration of high temperatures during the growing season.

column20: 3 years of high mortality in 1957-1959; 30 years of disease prevalence; then another high mortality event in the mid 1980s; followed by much greater resistance. If I had to put one number to it, I would say 40 years
column24: Two high mortality events (30 years apart) apparently selected for resistant oyster genotypes. The high mortality events were correlated with reduced water flow from the Delaware river (and thus higher salinity). The parasite is susceptible to low salinity, and the second mortality event occurred in the upper bay region, which typically has a lower salinity _ but not during the second event (due to reduced Delaware flow).
column29: Widespread mortality events may select for resistant genotypes that contribute to the majority of offspring, and thus confer resistance to the population as a whole. In contrast, localized mortality events may confer little resilience to the •metapopulationê if larvae from •´veê subpopulations greatly outnumber larvae from the resistant subpopulation. Environmental variability is a potential driver of localized mortality events, due to the physical requirements of the pathogen. Therefore, in the short-term, subpopulations offer the potential for recovery of the entire population through the supply of susceptible larvae. But in the long-term, these subpopulations are reducing the resistance of the entire population.

column24: Presence of seagrass prevented loss of macrofaunal community
column29: The authors sampled macrofauna diversity at two seagrass sites before and after the Tsunami. At one site, the Tsunami's effects were huge - and it ripped out all of the vegetation. Thus, at this site, the presence of seagrass had no effect on recovery or diversity. At the other site, the Tsunami's effects were more moderate. Here, the seagrass stayed intact and the authors hypothesize that the seagrass was able to buffer some of the physical disturbance and help the macrofaunal community resist the effects. The authors primarily talk about recovery, but I would call this resistance.

column24: Overfishing may stabilize the stable state with a lower carrying capacity. Rates of natural mortality and recruitment contribute to the uncertainty of the magnitude of surplus reduction, but are probably secondary to overfishing in the maintence of the lower state.
column29: This paper compares a 54 year time series of oyster abundances to model predictions of multiple stables. The time series suggests two states with different carrying capacities: From 1953-1968 and 1987 - 2005, K ~ 12e9 individuals, but from 1969 - 1986, K ~ 2e9 individuals. The authors discuss the 'resistance' of the lower K state to transition towards the higher K state, and suggest that overfishing may stabilize the lower K state. A model with high natural morality and low recruitment is thought to really prevent the transition to the higher K state (desirable from a fishing magement perspective). Take home message: Most fisheries magement assumes that a single stable state exists, with a single carry capacity. The oyster fishery in New Jersey may exhibit two states, with different Kês. Ideally, magement would want to •pushê the system into the higher K state, but current overfishing may •lockê the system into the lower K state. High rates of tural mortality and low recruitment may contribute to hysteresis. It is worth noting that this modeling exercise is based on a time series that exhibits the low K state, then the high K state, and then low state. SoÄnot much replication. Also, from a strict stable states perspective, it is not clear that there wasnêt a shift in the abiotic conditions (which would not make it ASS).

This is a study about predicting changes from rising sea temperatures. No focus on resilience. They used an 18-year sampling program around the thermal outfall of a power-generating station. They obsreved significant community-wide changes in 150species of algae and invertebrates relative to adjacent control areas experiencing turaltemperatures. Key results were that after a sustained rise in sea-water temperature the great majority of nearshore spe-cies changed in abundance and whole communities changed in character.

The paper is a commentary on global planetary (not marine necessarily) tipping points that should not be crossed. These are climate change, biodiversity loss, changes to nitrogen/phosphorus cycles, ozone depletion, ocean acidification, fresh water use, change in land use, chemical pollution, and atmospheric aerosol loading.

column2: GASCÓN S, BRUCET S, BOIX D, SALA J & QUINTA X.D. 2007. Comparison of the effects of hydrological disturbance events on benthos and plankton salt marsh communities. Estuarine Coastal and Shelf Science, 74 (3): 419-428.
column29: The study compared community response of macrobenthos and zooplankton in different environments to hydrologic disturbance. Zooplankton (which have fast reaction times) show community patterns based on climatic conditions and less to their specific environment. As such they are resilient to hydological disturbances. Macrobenthos (which have slower reaction times) are more adapted to their habitats and are more severely affected by disturbance.

column2: McKee, K.L., and W.H. Patrick. 1988. The relationship of smooth cordgrass (Sparti alterniflora) to tidal datums: A review. Estuaries 11: 143_151.
column29: This review paper looked at the relationship between distribution of Spartina alterniflora relative to the tidal level. Results suggest that the vertical distribution of S. alterniflora is primarily driven by the tidal range of a site, but other abiotic and biotic factors play a role as well. No mention of disturbance recovery or resilience.

column2: Mendelssohn, I.A., and J.T. Morris. 2000. Eco-physiological controls on the productivity of Sparti alterniflora Loisel. In Concepts and controversies in tidal marsh ecology, ed. M.P. Weinstein and D.A. Kreeger, 59_80. Dordrecht: Kluwer Academic.
column29: This was a review paper looking at the mechanisms determining Sparti alterniflira prudoctuvity, particularly cycles related to soil anoxia, sulfide and salinity and ammonia uptake.

column2: Badosa et al, Estuarine Coastal and Shelf Science, 2007

column29: Paper was about fish abundances, not about seagrasses--perhaps the paper is from a different year or a different journal?

column2: Orth, R.J., Carruthers, T. J. B.,Dennison, W. C., Duarte, C.M., Fourqurean, J.W., Heck, Jr., K. L., Randall Hughes, A., Kendrick, G. A., Kenworthy, W. J.,Olyarnik, S., Short, F. T., Waycott, M., Williams, S. L. 2006. A global crisis for seagrass ecosystems. Bioscience 56(12): 987-996.
column29: This paper only discussed seagrass losses and potential for restoration via management plans, but did not actually discuss seagrass restoration or resilience

column24: N/A
column29: about biological and landscape metrics to evaluate estuarine health. Not about seagrass per se or resilience.
Monitoring guide, not report on reslience.

column2: Mcleod et al. (2011) Frontier in the Ecological Environment
column29: This is a review paper on Carbon release and loss of carbon sinks, as result of mangrove deforestation. No instances given of lack of carbon release in spite of deforestation (not possible) so, instead is thorough review of amounts of carbon released as result of mangrove deforestation in different areas and forest types/sizes/

column24: Reef fish herbivory
column29: The authors used an observatiol study to show that macroalgae cover was low and coral cover high on reserve reefs compared with fished reefs, while the biomass and diversity of herbivorous fishes was highest in the reserves. They went on to experimentally transplant different species of macroalgae from fished reefs into the reserves to show that they were in fact consumed, and that while different species of herbivorous fish were important for tackling different species of algae (feeding complementarity), four species of fish accounted for 97% of the macroalgae removal. They next extracted chemicals from specific algae and painted them on the fronds of other species to confirm the chemical mechanism behind both the algal defenses and feeding specialities of the herbivores. Filly, they developed a variety of models to confirm the important role of herbivore diversity in controlling algal abundance on these reefs.

column2: Doherty, J. M., C. Callaway, and J. B. Zedler. 2011. Diversity-function relationships changed in a long-term restoration experiment. Ecological Applications 21: 2143-2155.
column29: This was a restoration effort testing biodiversity - ecosystem function hypotheses.  Site is a dynamic estuary where increased flooding was altering habitat for endangered wildlife.  No real measure or mention of success was given, but all treatments converged on similar levels of function, thus I interpreted it to be a success

This paper discusses the results of a restoration exeriment (using marl mounds and hatchery-raised juvenile oysters set on recycled shell), aiming at indentifying factors facilitating restoration success. They conclude that that seeding does not enhance oyster reef restoration efforts in Pamlico Sound. Fincial resources used for oyster seed would be better used to increase the amount of substrate for oyster settlement.

This paper discusses the results of a restoration exeriment, aiming at indentifying factors facilitating restoration success. They constructed tive oyster reefs of three types (high-relief, low-relief, and unrestored) in nine protected sanctuaries throughout the Great Wicomico River in Virginia, United States. Upon sampling in 2007 and 2009, they found a thriving metapopulation comprising 185 million oysters of various age classes. Oyster density was fourfold greater on high-relief than on low-relief reefs, explaining the failure of past attempts. Juvenile recruitment and reef accretion correlated with oyster density, facilitating reef development and population persistence.

This is a review and discussion of metapopulation dymics of Giant Kelp. There are some references within the review that might be helpful. This review mentions that Giant Kelp can recover without immigration if benthic microscopic stages survive a disturbance. example is Ladah et al. 1999 in Baja.

column2: Wilson SK, Graham J, Pratchett MS, Jones GP, Polunin NVC (2006) Multiple disturbances and the global degradation of coral reefs: are reef fishes at risk or resilient? Global Change Biology 12:2220-2234
column20: short term (<3 years of disturbance) responses assessed
column29: Meta-alysis of impacts of habitat change on reef fish. Shows different groups of fish impacted based on their diet and body size. Loss of structural complexity of the reef more important that loss of live coral for most groups.

column2: Steneck RS et al. Env. Cons. 2002
column24: Fishing, deseases, other predators or any other factors controlling sea urchins; higher diversity of functiolly important species in kelp forests (e.g. increasing stability and resilience to species invasions)
column29: Revovery was years - decades. This is a review focused on shifts from kelps to urchin barrens globally, therefore the focus is mainly on top down effects cascading through tropic webs. The authors conclude that magement should focus on minimizing fishing impacts and restoring populations of functiolly important species

column24: Lack of fishing
column29: Long time series needed critical to evaluate recovery

column2: Boudouresque C.F., Berrd G., Pergent G., Shili A., Verlaque M., 2009. Regression of Mediterranean seagrasses caused by natural processes and anthropogenic disturbances and stress: a critical review. Botanica Mari, 52: 395_418
column12: "the greatest magnitude of the forcing that can be tolerated by the variable, so that the population or the ecosystem recovers to previous control values (GESAMP 1995)."

column29: This report lists ideas for promoting seagrass resilience, but does not explore these examples in depth. The papers cited as examples of resilience and recovery might be better examples to use in this literature review.

column2: Montefalcone, Ecological Indicators (2009), Ecosystem health assessment using the Mediterranean seagrass Posidonia oceanica: A review.
column29: This review paper advocated for transitioning from a water quality-focused approach to assessing coastal ecosystems to an approach combining water quality and ecological indices (the Conservation Index, Substitution Index, and the Phase Shift Index). The paper discusses focusing on different levels (individual, population, community) and focuses specifically on one species, counting colonization by other seagrasses differently from maintained colonization of P. oceanica (the species of interest) differently from complete loss of all seagrasses.

column2: Garrido et al., 2013. Resilience and stability of Cymodocea nodosa seagrass meadows over the last four decades in a Mediterranean lagoon. Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science 130 (2013) 89-98.
column24: mild temperatures in winter (February) and early spring (April); increased oxygen levels
column29: Overall, there was a 49% regression in seagrass distribution from the early 1970s thru the early 1990s, then a 42% increase from the early 1990s to time of publishing. However, this study compares change over time through spshots of the environment and methodology was variable throughout the study, so the results may not be as accurate as desired.

column2: Walker, D.I., Kendrick, G.A., McComb, A.J. 2006. Decline and recovery of seagrass ecosystems _ the dymics of change. In: Seagrass Biology (Eds. Larkum, AWD, Orth RJ and Duarte, C.) Elsevier
column24: Heterogeneous communities with faster-growing species in combination with mono-specific meadow-forming species and higher flushing rates
column29: This is a review paper with multiple case studies, discussing patterns of seagrass loss and potential factors for resilience.
Review indicating that most important factor for mangroves will be sea level rise (not keeping up).

column2: fagherazzi et al review of geophysics 2012
column24: Based on review of others:(1) High mineral sediment availability in marshes adjacent to tidal channels ebles faster adjustment to increased sea level compared to inetrior marshes (D'Alpaos, 2011)(2) Estuarine marshes with low tidal ranges and little mineral sediment are more vulnerable to SLR (Reed, 1995)(3) In absence of vegetation, feedback processes lead to rapid elevation loss that further precludes the return of vegetation (Delaune et al. 1994, Fagherazzi et al. 2006, Marani et al. 2007, Kirwan et al. 2008)(4) Based on computer simulations, in the absence of dykes, marsh expansion could account for loss of saltmarsh due to SLR (Kirwan & Murray, 2008)
column27: Low mineral sediment supply and small tidal range
column29: This review focused mainly on history of saltmarsh hydrogromorphologic modelling, discussing the shortcomings and strengths of different models, and identifying future work needed. Some examples of resilience or lack of resilience were given.

column2: Waycott, Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and Australian Greenhouse Office, 2007
column24: adaptation and recolonization
column29: This book chapter summarizes factors impacting seagrass resilience and recovery to stressors. I think the citations may be more useful as specific examples of seagrass resilience and recovery.

column17: Various: - some were pulse events (el Ninos) while others were press disturbances (urban developments and seawage discharges)
column19: Various: - some were pulse events (el Ninos) while others were press disturbances (urban developments and seawage discharges)
column24: reduction of the stressors that caused the decline (mainly water quality that is coastal runoff, increased sedimentation, and contamition impact) Note: They contrast the prevailing view (e.g. Tegner & Dayton 1991) that urchin fishery contributes to resilience, based on their review they say it is the other way round (urchin fishery is abundant when kelp forests are healthy and provide more algal drift to feed the urchins)
column28: Additional biotic disturbances (e.g., disease, population outbreaks, grazing)
column29: this is a comphensive review of all the literature (from the early 1900s onwards) on the status of kelp forests along southern California coasts and the underlying processes that drive their structure. As such it covers all other papers from southern California. They focus on the severe declines in kelp forests near large metropolitan areas along the southern portion of the mainland coast of southern California, associated with coastal development, sedimentation and sewage outfalls. They conclude that recovery of kelp occurred when stressors were reduced, and there was no evidence for a general collapse of kelp forest structure or a permanent shift to a largely kelp-free state. They comment that it is remarkable that macrocystis is so robust and that kelp forests flourish in virtually all areas now that they occupied historically. The weedy life history of M. pyrifera ebles relatively quick replenishment of populations even after such major oceanographic events such as the 1982_83 El Ni_o that deforested large areas of kelp forest along the entire California coast.

column2: Cort_s, J., C.E. Jim_nez, A.C. Fonseca & J.J. Alvarado. 2010. Status and conservation of coral reefs in Costa Rica. Revista de BiologÍa Tropical, 58 (Supplement 1): 33-50.
column24: human protection, distance from human communities, limited sediment load, upwelling on hte Pacifc side
column29: Nice review of what occured simultaneoulsy in two different oceanic basins that affected Costa Rican coral reefs. Authors implied that cooled upwelled waters on the Pacific might have helped in resisting the ENSO and warming impacts.

column2: Pergent et al., 2014. Climate change and Mediterranean seagrass meadows: a synopsis for environmental mager. Mediterranean Marine Science, in press
column24: lack of strong anthropogenic pressures (pristine environments)
column29: This paper focuses on how seagrasses can mitigate the consequences of climate change through NPP. Some local and/or invasive seagrasses began to colonize areas where there were die-offs, but overall, there has been a decline in seagrass cover.

column24: conservation and restoration initiatives
column29: This is a global review on the (poor) global status of oyster reefs. It focuses on options for the conservation of the few remaining populations and for restoration (as tural recovery of tive populations is not possible in many cases)

column2: Folke et al. Ann Rev Ecol
column12: Holling (1973), in his seminal paper, defined ecosystem resilience as the magnitude. we define resilience as the capacity of a system to absorb disturbance andreorganize while undergoing change so as to retain essentially the same function,structure, identity, and feedbacks (Walker et al. 2004).of disturbance that a system can experience before it shifts into a differentstate (stability domain) with different controls on structure and function and distinguishedecosystem resilience from engineering resilience.
column29: Review of phase shifts in multiple ecosystems

column2: Zedler, J. B. 2010. How frequent storms affect wetland vegetation: A preview of climate change impacts. Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment 8:540-547.
column20: Various. Main case study of Tijua Estuary recorded 27 years of increased storminess beginning 1978 (due to Pacific Decadal Oscillation) coinciding with strong winds due to ENSO event in 1983
column29: This was a review paper looking at potential effects of future climate on saltmarshes. Examples given pertain to when unexpected weather events led to changes in saltmarsh diversity (usually reduction). Some suggestions were given to enhance resilience of diversity, but these were untested.

column24: Coral reefs = maintaining herbivory, kelp forests = reducing sea urchins; seagrass beds, restoring food webs and removing ephemeral algae, Oyster reefs = spatially extensive habitat restoration (>35 ha) and ban on harvest, providing high relief vertical habitats
column29: possibly useful paper for group to read as focusing on similar habitat types but with different focus

column2: Lejeusne C., Chevaldonn_ P., Pergent-Martini C., Boudouresque C.F., Perez T., 2010. Climate change effects on a miniature ocean: The highly diverse, highly impacted Mediterranean Sea. Trends in Ecology and Evolution, 25(4): 250-260
column29: Broad review of climated-associated changes in marine benthic communities of the Mediterranean. Focus is on how much has already changed, and how diseases can impede recovery from climate disturbances.
